sp.l: The Count Roussillon. Know you such a one?

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: But by the ear, that hears most nobly of him.
His face I know not.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Whatsome’er he is,
He’s bravelytaken here. He stole from France,
As ’tis reported, for the King had married him
Against his liking. Think you it is so?

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: Ay, surely, mere the truth, I know his lady.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: There is a gentleman that serves the Count
Reports but coarsely of her.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: What’s his name?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Monsieur Parolles.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: O, I believe with him.
In argument of praise, or to the worth
Of the great Count himself, she is too mean
To have her name repeated. All her deserving
Is a reservedhonesty, and that
I have not heard examin’d.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Alas, poor lady,
’Tis a hard bondage to become the wife
Of a detesting lord.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: I warr’nt, good creature, wheresoe’er she is,
Her heart weighs sadly. This young maid might do her
A shrewd turn, if she pleas’d.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: How do you mean?
May be the amorous Count solicits her
In the unlawful purpose.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: He does indeed,
And brokes with all that can in such a suit
Corrupt the tender honor of a maid.
But she is arm’d for him, and keeps her guard
In honestest defense.

stage.dir: Drum and Colors. Enter (Bertram) Count Roussillon, Parolles, and the whole army.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: The gods forbid else!

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: So, now they come.
That is Antonio, the Duke’s eldest son,
That, Escalus.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: Which is the Frenchman?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: He,
That with the plume; ’tis a most gallant fellow.
I would he lov’d his wife. If he were honester
He were much goodlier. Is’t not a handsome gentleman?

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: I like him well.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: ’Tis pity he is not honest. Yond’s that same knave
That leads him to these places. Were I his lady,
I would poison that vile rascal.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: Which is he?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: That jack-an-apes with scarfs. Why is he melancholy?

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: Perchance he’s hurt i’ th’ battle.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Lose our drum! Well.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: He’s shrewdly vex’d at something. Look, he has spied us.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Marry, hang you!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: And your courtesy, for a ring-carrier!

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: The troop is past. Come, pilgrim, I will bring you
Where you shall host. Of enjoin’d penitents
There’s four or five, to great Saint Jaques bound,
Already at my house.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: I humbly thank you.
Please it this matron and this gentle maid
To eat with us tonight, the charge and thanking
Shall be for me, and to requite you further,
I will bestow some precepts of this virgin
Worthy the note.

sp.speaker: BOTH MAR. AND WID.
sp.l: We’ll take your offer kindly.

stage.dir: Enter (Bertram) Count Roussillon and the two French Lords.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Nay, good my lord, put him to’t; let him have his way.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: If your lordship find him not a hilding, hold me no more in your respect.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: On my life, my lord, a bubble.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Do you think I am so far deceiv’d in him?

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Believe it, my lord, in mine own direct knowledge, without any malice, but to speak of him as my kinsman, he’s a most notable coward, an infinite and endless liar, an hourly promise-breaker, the owner of no one good quality worthy your lordship’s entertainment.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: It were fit you knew him, lest reposing too far in his virtue, which he hath not, he might at some great and trusty business in a main danger fail you.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: I would I knew in what particular action to try him.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: None better than to let him fetch off his drum, which you hear him so confidently undertake to do.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: I, with a troop of Florentines, will suddenly surprise him; such I will have, whom I am sure he knows not from the enemy. We will bind and hoodwink him so, that he shall suppose no other but that he is carried into the leaguer of the adversaries, when we bring him to our own tents. Be but your lordship present at his examination, if he do not, for the promise of his life, and in the highest compulsion of base fear, offer to betray you, and deliver all the intelligence in his power against you, and that with the divine forfeit of his soul upon oath, never trust my judgment in any thing.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: O, for the love of laughter, let him fetch his drum; he says he has a stratagem for’t. When your lordship sees the bottom of his success in’t, and to what metal this counterfeit lump of ore will be melted, if you give him not John Drum’s entertainment, your inclining cannot be remov’d. Here he comes.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: O, for the love of laughter, hinder not the honor of his design. Let him fetch off his drum in any hand.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: How now, monsieur? This drum stickssorely in your disposition.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: A pox on’t, let it go, ’tis but a drum.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: But a drum! Is’t but a drum? A drum so lost! There was excellent command—to charge in with our horse upon our own wings, and to rend our own soldiers!

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: That was not to be blam’d in the command of the service; it was a disaster of war that Caesar himself could not have prevented, if he had been there to command.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Well, we cannot greatly condemn our success. Some dishonor we had in the loss of that drum, but it is not to be recover’d.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: It might have been recover’d.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: It might, but it is not now.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: It is to be recover’d. But that the merit of service is seldom attributed to the true and exact performer, I would have that drum or another, or hic jacet.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Why, if you have a stomach, to’t, monsieur: if you think your mystery in stratagem can bring this instrument of honor again into his native quarter, be magnanimious in the enterprise and go on; I will grace the attempt for a worthy exploit. If you speed well in it, the Duke shall both speak of it, and extend to you what further becomes his greatness, even to the utmost syllable of your worthiness.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: By the hand of a soldier, I will undertake it.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: But you must not now slumber in it.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I’ll about it this evening, and I will presently pen down my dilemmas, encourage myself in my certainty, put myself into my mortal preparation; and by midnight look to hear further from me.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: May I be bold to acquaint his Grace you are gone about it?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I know not what the success will be, my lord, but the attempt I vow.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: I know th’ art valiant, and to the possibility of thy soldiership will subscribe for thee. Farewell.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I love not many words.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: No more than a fish loves water. Is not this a strange fellow, my lord, that so confidently seems to undertake this business, which he knows is not to be done, damns himself to do, and dares better be damn’d than to do’t?

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: You do not know him, my lord, as we do. Certain it is that he will steal himself into a man’s favor, and for a week escape a great deal of discoveries, but when you find him out, you have him ever after.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Why, do you think he will make no deed at all of this that so seriously he does address himself unto?

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: None in the world, but return with an invention, and clap upon you two or three probable lies. But we have almost emboss’d him, you shall see his fall tonight; for indeed he is not for your lordship’s respect.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: We’ll make you some sport with the fox ere we case him. He was first smok’d by the old Lord Lafew. When his disguise and he is parted, tell me what a sprat you shall find him, which you shall see this very night.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: I must go look my twigs. He shall be caught.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Your brother he shall go along with me.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: As’t please your lordship. I’ll leave you.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Now will I lead you to the house, and show you
The lass I spoke of.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: But you say she’s honest.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: That’s all the fault. I spoke with her but once,
And found her wondrous cold, but I sent to her,
By this same coxcomb that we have i’ th’ wind,
Tokens and letters which she did re-send,
And this is all I have done. She’s a fair creature;
Will you go see her?

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: With all my heart, my lord.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: If you misdoubt me that I am not she,
I know not how I shall assure you further
But I shall lose the grounds I work upon.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Though my estate be fall’n, I was well born,
Nothing acquainted with these businesses,
And would not put my reputation now
In any staining act.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: Nor would I wish you.
First give me trust, the Count he is my husband,
And what to your sworncounsel I have spoken
Is so from word to word; and then you cannot,
By the good aid that I of you shall borrow,
Err in bestowing it.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: I should believe you,
For you have show’d me that which well approves
Y’ are great in fortune.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: Take this purse of gold,
And let me buy your friendly help thus far,
Which I will over-pay and pay again
When I have found it. The Count he woos your daughter,
Lays down his wanton siege before her beauty,
Resolv’d to carry her. Let her in fine consent,
As we’ll direct her how ’tis best to bear it.
Now his important blood will nought deny
That she’ll demand. A ring the County wears,
That downward hath succeeded in his house
From son to son, some four or five descents,
Since the first father wore it. This ring he holds
In most rich choice; yet in his idlefire,
To buy his will, it would not seem too dear,
Howe’er repented after.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Now I see
The bottom of your purpose.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: You see it lawful then. It is no more
But that your daughter, ere she seems as won,
Desires this ring; appoints him an encounter;
In fine, delivers me to fill the time,
Herself most chastely absent. After,
To marry her, I’ll add three thousand crowns
To what is pass’d already.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: I have yielded.
Instruct my daughter how she shall persever,
That time and place with this deceit so lawful
May prove coherent. Every night he comes
With musics of all sorts, and songs compos’d
To her unworthiness. It nothing steads us
To chide him from our eaves, for he persists
As if his life lay on’t.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: Why then tonight
Let us assay our plot, which if it speed,
Is wicked meaning in a lawful deed,
And lawful meaning in a lawful act,
Where both not sin, and yet a sinful fact.
But let’s about it.

stage.dir: Enter Second French Lord with five or six other Soldiers in ambush.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner. When you sally upon him, speak what terrible language you will. Though you understand it not yourselves, no matter; for we must not seem to understand him, unless some one among us, whom we must produce for an interpreter.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Good captain, let me be th’ interpreter.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Art not acquainted with him? Knows he not thy voice?

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: No, sir, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: But what linsey-woolsey hast thou to speak to us again?

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: E’en such as you speak to me.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: He must think us some band of strangers i’ th’ adversary’s entertainment. Now he hath a smack of all neighboring languages; therefore we must every one be a man of his own fancy, not to know what we speak one to another; so we seem to know, is to know straight our purpose: choughs’ language, gabble enough, and good enough. As for you, interpreter, you must seem very politic. But couch ho, here he comes, to beguile two hours in a sleep, and then to return and swear the lies he forges.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Ten o’clock: within these three hours ’twill be time enough to go home. What shall I say I have done? It must be a very plausiveinvention that carries it. They begin to smoke me, and disgraces have of late knock’d too often at my door. I find my tongue is too foolhardy, but my heart hath the fear of Mars before it, and of his creatures, not daring the reports of my tongue.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: This is the first truth that e’er thine own tongue was guilty of.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: What the devil should move me to undertake the recovery of this drum, being not ignorant of the impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose? I must give myself some hurts, and say I got them in exploit. Yet slight ones will not carry it. They will say, “Came you off with so little?” And great ones I dare not give; wherefore what’s the instance? Tongue, I must put you into a butter-woman’s mouth and buy myself another of Bajazeth’s mule, if you prattle me into these perils.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Is it possible he should know what he is, and be that he is?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I would the cutting of my garments would serve the turn, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: We cannot afford you so.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Or the baring of my beard, and to say it was in stratagem.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: ’Twould not do.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripp’d.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Hardly serve.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Though I swore I leapt from the window of the citadel⁠—

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: How deep?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Thirty fathom.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Three great oaths would scarce make that be believ’d.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I would I had any drum of the enemy’s. I would swear I recover’d it.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: You shall hear one anon.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: A drum now of the enemy’s⁠—

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: O, ransom, ransom!
Do not hide mine eyes.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I know you are the Muskos’ regiment,
And I shall lose my life for want of language.
If there be here German, or Dane, Low Dutch,
Italian, or French, let him speak to me,
I’ll discover that which shall undo the Florentine.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Boskos vauvado. I understand thee, and can speak thy tongue. Kerelybonto, sir, betake thee to thy faith, for seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: O!

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: O, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: The general is content to spare thee yet,
And hoodwink’d as thou art, will lead thee on
To gather from thee. Haply thou mayst inform
Something to save thy life.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: O, let me live,
And all the secrets of our camp I’ll show,
Their force, their purposes; nay, I’ll speak that
Which you will wonder at.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: But wilt thou faithfully?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: If I do not, damn me.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Come on, thou art granted space,

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Go tell the Count Roussillon, and my brother,
We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffled
Till we do hear from them.

sp.speaker: 2. SOLD.
sp.l: Captain, I will.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: ’A will betray us all unto ourselves:
Inform on that.

sp.speaker: 2. SOLD.
sp.l: So I will, sir.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Till then I’ll keep him dark and safely lock’d.

stage.dir: Enter Bertram and the maid called Diana.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: They told me that your name was Fontibell.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: No, my good lord, Diana.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Titled goddess,
And worth it, with addition! But, fair soul,
In your fine frame hath love no quality?
If the quick fire of youth light not your mind,
You are no maiden, but a monument.
When you are dead, you should be such a one
As you are now; for you are cold and stern,
And now you should be as your mother was
When your sweet self was got.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: She then was honest.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: So should you be.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: No;
My mother did but duty, such, my lord,
As you owe to your wife.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: No more a’ that.
I prithee do not strive against my vows.
I was compell’d to her, but I love thee
By love’s own sweet constraint, and will forever
Do thee all rights of service.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Ay, so you serve us
Till we serve you; but when you have our roses,
You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves,
And mock us with our bareness.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: How have I sworn!

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: ’Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth,
But the plain single vow that is vow’d true.
What is not holy, that we swear not by,
But take the High’st to witness. Then pray you tell me,
If I should swear by Jove’s great attributes
I lov’d you dearly, would you believe my oaths
When I did love you ill? This has no holding,
To swear by Him whom I protest to love
That I will work against Him; therefore your oaths
Are words and poor conditions, but unseal’d⁠—
At least in my opinion.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Change it, change it!
Be not so holy-cruel. Love is holy,
And my integrity ne’er knew the crafts
That you do charge men with. Stand no more off,
But give thyself unto my sick desires,
Who then recovers. Say thou art mine, and ever
My love, as it begins, shall so persever.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: I see that men make rope’s in such a scarre,
That we’ll forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: I’ll lend it thee, my dear; but have no power
To give it from me.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Will you not, my lord?

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: It is an honor’longing to our house,
Bequeathed down from many ancestors,
Which were the greatest obloquy i’ th’ world
In me to lose.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Mine honor’s such a ring,
My chastity’s the jewel of our house,
Bequeathed down from many ancestors,
Which were the greatest obloquy i’ th’ world
In me to lose. Thus your own proper wisdom
Brings in the champion Honor on my part,
Against your vain assault.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Here, take my ring!
My house, mine honor, yea, my life, be thine,
And I’ll be bid by thee.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: When midnight comes, knock at my chamber-window;
I’ll order take my mother shall not hear.
Now will I charge you in the band of truth,
When you have conquer’d my yet maiden bed,
Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me.
My reasons are most strong, and you shall know them
When back again this ring shall be deliver’d;
And on your finger in the night I’ll put
Another ring, that what in time proceeds
May token to the future our past deeds.
Adieu till then, then fail not. You have won
A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: For which live long to thank both heaven and me!
You may so in the end.
My mother told me just how he would woo,
As if she sate in ’s heart. She says all men
Have the like oaths. He had sworn to marry me
When his wife’s dead; therefore I’ll lie with him
When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid,
Marry that will, I live and die a maid.
Only in this disguise I think’t no sin
To cozen him that would unjustly win.

stage.dir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: You have not given him his mother’s letter?

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: I have deliv’red it an hour since. There is something in’t that stings his nature; for on the reading it he chang’d almost into another man.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shaking off so good a wife and so sweet a lady.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Especially he hath incurr’d the everlasting displeasure of the King, who had even tun’d his bounty to sing happiness to him. I will tell you a thing, but you shall let it dwelldarkly with you.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: When you have spoken it, ’tis dead, and I am the grave of it.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in Florence, of a most chaste renown, and this night he fleshes his will in the spoil of her honor. He hath given her his monumental ring, and thinks himself made in the unchaste composition.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Now God delay our rebellion! As we are ourselves, what things are we!

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Merely our own traitors. And as in the common course of all treasons, we still see them reveal themselves, till they attain to their abhorr’d ends; so he that in this action contrives against his own nobility in his proper stream o’erflows himself.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Is it not meantdamnable in us, to be trumpeters of our unlawful intents? We shall not then have his company tonight?

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Not till after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: That approaches apace. I would gladly have him see his companyanatomiz’d, that he might take a measure of his own judgments, wherein so curiously he had set this counterfeit.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: We will not meddle with him till he come; for his presence must be the whip of the other.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: In the meantime, what hear you of these wars?

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: I hear there is an overture of peace.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Nay, I assure you a peace concluded.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: What will Count Roussillon do then? Will he travel higher, or return again into France?

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: I perceive by this demand, you are not altogether of his counsel.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Let it be forbid, sir, so should I be a great deal of his act.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Sir, his wife some two months since fled from his house. Her pretense is a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques le Grand; which holy undertaking with most austere sanctimony she accomplish’d; and there residing, the tenderness of her nature became as a prey to her grief; in fine, made a groan of her last breath, and now she sings in heaven.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: How is this justified?

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: The stronger part of it by her own letters, which makes her story true, even to the point of her death. Her death itself, which could not be her office to say is come, was faithfully confirm’d by the rector of the place.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Hath the Count all this intelligence?

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Ay, and the particular confirmations, point from point, to the full arming of the verity.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: I am heartily sorry that he’ll be glad of this.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our losses!

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: And how mightily some other times we drown our gain in tears! The great dignity that his valor hath here acquir’d for him shall at home be encount’red with a shame as ample.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and ill together: our virtues would be proud, if our faults whipt them not, and our crimes would despair, if they were not cherish’d by our virtues.
How now? Where’s your master?

sp.speaker: MESS.
sp.l: He met the Duke in the street, sir, of whom he hath taken a solemn leave. His lordship will next morning for France. The Duke hath offer’d him letters of commendations to the King.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: They shall be no more than needful there, if they were more than they can commend.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: They cannot be too sweet for the King’s tartness. Here’s his lordship now. How now, my lord, is’t not after midnight?

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: I have tonight dispatch’d sixteen businesses, a month’s length a-piece, by an abstract of success: I have congied with the Duke, done my adieu with his nearest; buried a wife, mourn’d for her, writ to my lady mother I am returning, entertain’d my convoy, and between these main parcels of dispatch effected many nicer needs. The last was the greatest, but that I have not ended yet.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: If the business be of any difficulty, and this morning your departure hence, it requires haste of your lordship.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: I mean the business is not ended, as fearing to hear of it hereafter. But shall we have this dialogue between the fool and the soldier? Come, bring forth this counterfeitmodule, h’as deceiv’d me like a double-meaning prophesier.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Bring him forth, h’as sate i’ th’ stocks all night, poor gallantknave.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: No matter, his heels have deserv’d it, in usurping his spurs so long. How does he carry himself?

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: I have told your lordship already: the stocks carry him. But to answer you as you would be understood, he weeps like a wench that had shed her milk. He hath confess’d himself to Morgan, whom he supposes to be a friar, from the time of his remembrance to this very instant disaster of his setting i’ th’ stocks; and what think you he hath confess’d?

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Nothing of me, has ’a?

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: His confession is taken, and it shall be read to his face. If your lordship be in’t, as I believe you are, you must have the patience to hear it.

stage.dir: Enter Soldiers and Parolles, with First Soldier as his Interpreter.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: A plague upon him! Muffled! He can say nothing of me.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Hush, hush! Hoodman comes! Portotartarossa.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: He calls for the tortures. What will you say without ’em?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I will confess what I know without constraint. If ye pinch me like a pasty, I can say no more.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: You are a merciful general. Our general bids you answer to what I shall ask you out of a note.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: And truly, as I hope to live.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.

l.recite: “First demand of him, how many horse the Duke is strong.”

sp.l: What say you to that?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Five or six thousand, but very weak and unserviceable. The troops are all scatter’d, and the commanders very poor rogues, upon my reputation and credit and as I hope to live.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Shall I set down your answer so?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Do, I’ll take the sacrament on’t, how and which way you will.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: All’s one to him. What a past-saving slave is this!

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Y’ are deceiv’d, my lord, this is Monsieur Parolles, the gallant militarist—that was his own phrase—that had the whole theoric of war in the knot of his scarf, and the practice in the chape of his dagger.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: I will never trust a man again for keeping his sword clean, nor believe he can have every thing in him by wearing his apparel neatly.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Well, that’s set down.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: “Five or six thousand horse,” I said—I will say true— “or thereabouts,” set down, for I’ll speak truth.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: He’s very near the truth in this.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: But I con him no thanks for’t, in the nature he delivers it.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: “Poor rogues,” I pray you say.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Well, that’s set down.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I humbly thank you, sir. A truth’s a truth, the rogues are marvelous poor.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.

l.recite: “Demand of him, of what strength they are afoot.”

sp.l: What say you to that?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: By my troth, sir, if I were to live this present hour, I will tell true. Let me see: Spurio, a hundred and fifty; Sebastian, so many; Corambus, so many; Jaques, so many; Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowick, and Gratii, two hundred fifty each; mine own company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Bentii, two hundred fifty each; so that the muster-file, rotten and sound, upon my life, amounts not to fifteen thousand pole, half of the which dare not shake the snow from off their cassocks, lest they shake themselves to pieces.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: What shall be done to him?

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand of him my condition, and what credit I have with the Duke.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Well, that’s set down.

l.recite: “You shall demand of him, whether one Captain Dumaine be i’ th’ camp, a Frenchman; what his reputation is with the Duke; what his valor, honesty, and expertness in wars; or whether he thinks it were not possible with well-weighing sums of gold to corrupt him to a revolt.”

sp.l: What say you to this? What do you know of it?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I beseech you let me answer to the particular of the inter’gatories. Demand them singly.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Do you know this Captain Dumaine?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I know him. ’A was a botcher’sprentice in Paris, from whence he was whipt for getting the shrieve’sfool with child, a dumb innocent, that could not say him nay.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Nay, by your leave, hold your hands—though I know his brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Well, is this captain in the Duke of Florence’s camp?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Upon my knowledge, he is, and lousy.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Nay, look not so upon me; we shall hear of your lordship anon.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: What is his reputation with the Duke?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: The Duke knows him for no other but a poor officer of mine, and writ to me this other day to turn him out a’ th’ band. I think I have his letter in my pocket.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Marry, we’ll search.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: In good sadness, I do not know. Either it is there, or it is upon a file with the Duke’s other letters in my tent.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Here ’tis, here’s a paper. Shall I read it to you?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I do not know if it be it or no.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Our interpreter does it well.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Excellently.

l.recite: “Dian, the Count’s a fool, and full of gold”—

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: That is not the Duke’s letter, sir; that is an advertisement to a proper maid in Florence, one Diana, to take heed of the allurement of one Count Roussillon, a foolish idle boy, but for all that very ruttish. I pray you, sir, put it up again.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: Nay, I’ll read it first, by your favor.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: My meaning in’t, I protest, was very honest in the behalf of the maid; for I knew the young Count to be a dangerous and lascivious boy, who is a whale to virginity, and devours up all the fry it finds.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Damnable both-sides rogue!

l.recite: “When he swears oaths, bid him drop gold, and take it;
After he scores, he never pays the score.
Half won is match well made; match, and well make it;
He ne’er pays after-debts, take it before,
And say a soldier, Dian, told thee this:
Men are to mell with, boys are not to kiss;
For count of this, the Count’s a fool, I know it,
Who pays before, but not when he does owe it.
Thine, as he vow’d to thee in thine ear,
Parolles.”

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: He shall be whipt through the army with this rhyme in ’s forehead.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: This is your devoted friend, sir, the manifold linguist and the armipotent soldier.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: I could endure any thing before but a cat, and now he’s a cat to me.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: I perceive, sir, by the general’s looks, we shall be fain to hang you.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: My life, sir, in any case! Not that I am afraid to die, but that my offenses being many, I would repent out the remainder of nature. Let me live, sir, in a dungeon, i’ th’ stocks, or any where, so I may live.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: We’ll see what may be done, so you confess freely; therefore once more to this Captain Dumaine. You have answer’d to his reputation with the Duke, and to his valor; what is his honesty?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: He will steal, sir, an egg out of a cloister. For rapes and ravishments he parallels Nessus. He professes not keeping of oaths; in breaking ’em he is stronger than Hercules. He will lie, sir, with such volubility, that you would think truth were a fool. Drunkenness is his best virtue, for he will be swine-drunk, and in his sleep he does little harm, save to his bed-clothes about him; but they know his conditions, and lay him in straw. I have but little more to say, sir, of his honesty. He has every thing that an honest man should not have; what an honest man should have, he has nothing.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: I begin to love him for this.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: For this description of thine honesty? A pox upon him for me, he’s more and more a cat.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: What say you to his expertness in war?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Faith, sir, h’as led the drum before the English tragedians. To belie him I will not, and more of his soldiership I know not, except in that country he had the honor to be the officer at a place there call’d Mile-end, to instruct for the doubling of files. I would do the man what honor I can, but of this I am not certain.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: He hath out-villain’d villainy so far, that the rarity redeems him.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: A pox on him, he’s a cat still.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: His qualities being at this poor price, I need not to ask you if gold will corrupt him to revolt.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Sir, for a cardecue he will sell the fee-simple of his salvation, the inheritance of it, and cut th’ entail from all remainders, and a perpetual succession for it perpetually.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: What’s his brother, the other Captain Dumaine?

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Why does he ask him of me?

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: What’s he?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: E’en a crow a’ th’ same nest; not altogether so great as the first in goodness, but greater a great deal in evil. He excels his brother for a coward, yet his brother is reputed one of the best that is. In a retreat he outruns any lackey; marry, in coming on he has the cramp.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: If your life be sav’d, will you undertake to betray the Florentine?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Ay, and the captain of his horse, Count Roussillon.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: I’ll whisper with the general, and know his pleasure.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I’ll no more drumming, a plague of all drums! Only to seem to deserve well, and to beguile the supposition of that lascivious young boy the Count, have I run into this danger. Yet who would have suspected an ambush where I was taken?

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: There is no remedy, sir, but you must die. The general says, you that have so traitorously discover’d the secrets of your army, and made such pestiferous reports of men very nobly held, can serve the world for no honest use; therefore you must die. Come, headsman, off with his head.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: O Lord, sir, let me live, or let me see my death!

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: That shall you, and take your leave of all your friends.
So, look about you. Know you any here?

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Good morrow, noble captain.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: God bless you, Captain Parolles.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: God save you, noble captain.

sp.speaker: 2. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord Lafew? I am for France.

sp.speaker: 1. LORD. DUM.
sp.l: Good captain, will you give me a copy of the sonnet you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count Roussillon? And I were not a very coward, I’d compel it of you, but fare you well.

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: You are undone, captain, all but your scarf; that has a knot on’t yet.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Who cannot be crush’d with a plot?

sp.speaker: 1. SOLD. AS INTERPRETER.
sp.l: If you could find out a country where but women were that had receiv’d so much shame, you might begin an impudent nation. Fare ye well, sir, I am for France too. We shall speak of you there.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Yet am I thankful. If my heart were great,
’Twould burst at this. Captain I’ll be no more,
But I will eat and drink, and sleep as soft
As captain shall. Simply the thing I am
Shall make me live. Who knows himself a braggart,
Let him fear this; for it will come to pass
That every braggart shall be found an ass.
Rust sword, cool blushes, and, Parolles, live
Safest in shame! Being fool’d, by fool’ry thrive!
There’s place and means for every man alive.
I’ll after them.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: That you may well perceive I have not wrong’d you,
One of the greatest in the Christian world
Shall be my surety; ’fore whose throne ’tis needful,
Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneel.
Time was, I did him a desired office,
Dear almost as his life, which gratitude
Through flinty Tartar’s bosom would peep forth,
And answer thanks. I duly am inform’d
His Grace is at Marsellis, to which place
We have convenient convoy. You must know
I am supposed dead. The army breaking,
My husband hies him home, where heaven aiding,
And by the leave of my good lord the King,
We’ll be before our welcome.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Gentle madam,
You never had a servant to whose trust
Your business was more welcome.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: Nor you, mistress,
Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labor
To recompense your love. Doubt not but heaven
Hath brought me up to be your daughter’s dower,
As it hath fated her to be my motive
And helper to a husband. But O, strange men,
That can such sweet use make of what they hate,
When saucytrusting of the cozen’d thoughts
Defiles the pitchy night; so lust doth play
With what it loathes for that which is away⁠—
But more of this hereafter. You, Diana,
Under my poor instructions yet must suffer
Something in my behalf.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Let death and honesty
Go with your impositions, I am yours
Upon your will to suffer.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: Yet, I pray you:
But with the word the time will bring on summer,
When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns,
And be as sweet as sharp. We must away:
Our wagon is prepar’d, and time revives us.
All’s well that ends well! Still the fine’s the crown;
What e’er the course, the end is the renown.

stage.dir: Enter Clown, old Lady Countess, and Lafew.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: No, no, no, your son was misled with a snipt-taffeta fellow there, whose villainous saffron would have made all the unbak’d and doughy youth of a nation in his color. Your daughter-in-law had been alive at this hour, and your son here at home, more advanc’d by the King than by that red-tail’d humble-bee I speak of.

sp.speaker: COUNT.
sp.l: I would I had not known him; it was the death of the most virtuous gentlewoman that ever nature had praise for creating. If she had partaken of my flesh, and cost me the dearest groans of a mother, I could not have ow’d her a more rooted love.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: ’Twas a good lady, ’twas a good lady. We may pick a thousand salads ere we light on such another herb.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: Indeed, sir, she was the sweet marjoram of the salad, or rather the herb of grace.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: They are not herbs, you knave, they are nose-herbs.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: I am no great Nebuchadnezzar, sir, I have not much skill in grass.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Whether dost thou profess thyself—a knave or a fool?

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: A fool, sir, at a woman’s service, and a knave at a man’s.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Your distinction?

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: I would cozen the man of his wife and do his service.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: So you were a knave at his service indeed.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: And I would give his wife my bauble, sir, to do her service.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: I will subscribe for thee, thou art both knave and fool.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: At your service.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: Why, sir, if I cannot serve you, I can serve as great a prince as you are.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Who’s that? A Frenchman?

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: Faith, sir, ’a has an English name, but his fisnomy is more hotter in France than there.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: What prince is that?

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: The black prince, sir, alias the prince of darkness, alias the devil.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Hold thee, there’s my purse. I give thee not this to suggest thee from thy master thou talk’st of; serve him still.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: I am a woodland fellow, sir, that always lov’d a great fire, and the master I speak of ever keeps a good fire. But sure he is the prince of the world; let his nobility remain in ’s court. I am for the house with the narrow gate, which I take to be too little for pomp to enter. Some that humble themselves may, but the many will be too chill and tender, and they’ll be for the flow’ry way that leads to the broad gate and the great fire.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Go thy ways, I begin to be a-weary of thee, and I tell thee so before, because I would not fall out with thee. Go thy ways, let my horses be well look’d to, without any tricks.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: If I put any tricks upon ’em, sir, they shall be jades’ tricks, which are their own right by the law of nature.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: A shrewdknave and an unhappy.

sp.speaker: COUNT.
sp.l: So ’a is. My lord that’s gone made himself much sport out of him. By his authority he remains here, which he thinks is a patent for his sauciness, and indeed he has no pace, but runs where he will.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: I like him well, ’tis not amiss. And I was about to tell you, since I heard of the good lady’s death, and that my lord your son was upon his return home, I mov’d the King my master to speak in the behalf of my daughter, which in the minority of them both, his Majesty, out of a self-graciousremembrance, did first propose. His Highness hath promis’d me to do it, and to stop up the displeasure he hath conceiv’d against your son, there is no fitter matter. How does your ladyship like it?

sp.speaker: COUNT.
sp.l: With very much content, my lord, and I wish it happily effected.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: His Highness comes post from Marsellis, of as able body as when he number’d thirty. ’A will be here tomorrow, or I am deceiv’d by him that in such intelligence hath seldom fail’d.

sp.speaker: COUNT.
sp.l: It rejoices me, that I hope I shall see him ere I die. I have letters that my son will be here tonight. I shall beseech your lordship to remain with me till they meet together.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Madam, I was thinking with what manners I might safely be admitted.

sp.speaker: COUNT.
sp.l: You need but plead your honorable privilege.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Lady, of that I have made a bold charter, but I thank my God it holds yet.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: O madam, yonder’s my lord your son with a patch of velvet on ’s face. Whether there be a scar under’t or no, the velvet knows, but ’tis a goodly patch of velvet. His left cheek is a cheek of two pile and a half, but his right cheek is worn bare.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: A scar nobly got, or a noble scar, is a good liv’ry of honor; so belike is that.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: But it is your carbinado’d face.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Let us go see your son I pray you. I long to talk with the young noble soldier.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: Faith, there’s a dozen of ’em, with delicate fine hats, and most courteous feathers, which bow the head, and nod at every man.

stage.dir: Enter Helen, Widow, and Diana, with two Attendants.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: But this exceedingposting day and night
Must wear your spirits low; we cannot help it.
But since you have made the days and nights as one,
To wear your gentle limbs in my affairs,
Be bold you do so grow in my requital
As nothing can unroot you.
In happy time!
This man may help me to his Majesty’s ear,
If he would spend his power. God save you, sir.

sp.speaker: GENT.
sp.l: And you.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: Sir, I have seen you in the court of France.

sp.speaker: GENT.
sp.l: I have been sometimes there.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: I do presume, sir, that you are not fall’n
From the report that goes upon your goodness,
And therefore goaded with most sharp occasions,
Which laynice manners by, I put you to
The use of your own virtues, for the which
I shall continue thankful.

sp.speaker: GENT.
sp.l: What’s your will?

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: That it will please you
To give this poor petition to the King,
And aid me with that store of power you have
To come into his presence.

sp.speaker: GENT.
sp.l: The King’s not here.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: Not here, sir?

sp.speaker: GENT.
sp.l: Not indeed.
He hence remov’d last night, and with more haste
Than is his use.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: Lord, how we lose our pains!

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: All’s well that ends well yet,
Though time seem so adverse and means unfit.
I do beseech you, whither is he gone?

sp.speaker: GENT.
sp.l: Marry, as I take it, to Roussillon,
Whither I am going.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: I do beseech you, sir,
Since you are like to see the King before me,
Commend the paper to his gracious hand,
Which I presume shall render you no blame,
But rather make you thank your pains for it.
I will come after you with what good speed
Our means will make us means.

sp.speaker: GENT.
sp.l: This I’ll do for you.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: And you shall find yourself to be well thank’d,
What e’er falls more. We must to horse again.
Go, go, provide.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Good Master Lavatch, give my Lord Lafew this letter. I have ere now, sir, been better known to you, when I have held familiarity with fresher clothes; but I am now, sir, muddied in Fortune’s mood, and smell somewhat strong of her strong displeasure.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: Truly, Fortune’s displeasure is but sluttish if it smell so strongly as thou speak’st of. I will henceforth eat no fish of Fortune’s butt’ring. Prithee allow the wind.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Nay, you need not to stop your nose, sir; I spake but by a metaphor.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: Indeed, sir, if your metaphor stink, I will stop my nose, or against any man’s metaphor. Prithee get thee further.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Pray you, sir, deliver me this paper.

sp.speaker: CLO.
sp.l: Foh, prithee stand away. A paper from Fortune’s close-stool to give to a nobleman! Look here he comes himself.

Here is a purr of Fortune’s, sir, or of Fortune’s cat—but not a musk-cat—that has fall’n into the unclean fishpond of her displeasure, and as he says, is muddied withal. Pray you, sir, use the carp as you may, for he looks like a poor, decay’d, ingenious, foolish, rascally knave. I do pity his distress in my similes of comfort, and leave him to your lordship.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: My lord, I am a man whom Fortune hath cruelly scratch’d.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: And what would you have me to do? ’Tis too late to pare her nails now. Wherein have you play’d the knave with Fortune that she should scratch you, who of herself is a good lady, and would not have knaves thrive long under her? There’s a cardecue for you. Let the justices make you and Fortune friends; I am for other business.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I beseech your honor to hear me one single word.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: You beg a single penny more. Come, you shall ha’t; save your word.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: My name, my good lord, is Parolles.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: You beg more than “word” then. Cox my passion! Give me your hand. How does your drum?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: O my good lord, you were the first that found me!

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Was I, in sooth? And I was the first that lost thee.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: It lies in you, my lord, to bring me in some grace, for you did bring me out.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Out upon thee, knave! Dost thou put upon me at once both the office of God and the devil? One brings thee in grace, and the other brings thee out.
The King’s coming, I know by his trumpets. Sirrah, inquire further after me. I had talk of you last night; though you are a fool and a knave, you shall eat. Go to, follow.

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I praise God for you.

stage.dir: Flourish. Enter King, old Lady Countess, Lafew, the two French Lords, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: We lost a jewel of her, and our esteem
Was made much poorer by it; but your son,
As mad in folly, lack’d the sense to know
Her estimationhome.

sp.speaker: COUNT.
sp.l: ’Tis past, my liege,
And I beseech your Majesty to make it
Natural rebellion, done i’ th’ blade of youth,
When oil and fire, too strong for reason’s force,
O’erbears it, and burns on.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: My honor’d lady,
I have forgiven and forgotten all,
Though my revenges were highbent upon him,
And watch’d the time to shoot.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: This I must say⁠—
But first I beg my pardon—the young lord
Did to his Majesty, his mother, and his lady
Offense of mighty note; but to himself
The greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife
Whose beauty did astonish the survey
Of richest eyes, whose words all ears took captive,
Whose dear perfection hearts that scorn’d to serve
Humbly call’d mistress.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Praising what is lost
Makes the remembrance dear. Well, call him hither,
We are reconcil’d, and the first view shall kill
All repetition. Let him not ask our pardon,
The nature of his great offense is dead,
And deeper than oblivion we do bury
Th’ incensingrelics of it. Let him approach
A stranger, no offender; and inform him
So ’tis our will he should.

sp.speaker: GENT.
sp.l: I shall, my liege.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: What says he to your daughter? Have you spoke?

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: All that he is hath reference to your Highness.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Then shall we have a match. I have letters sent me
That sets him high in fame.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: He looks well on’t.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: I am not a day of season,
For thou mayst see a sunshine and a hail
In me at once. But to the brightest beams
Distracted clouds give way, so stand thou forth,
The time is fair again.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: My high-repentedblames,
Dear sovereign, pardon to me.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: All is whole,
Not one word more of the consumed time.
Let’s take the instant by the forward top;
For we are old, and on our quick’st decrees
Th’ inaudible and noiseless foot of time
Steals ere we can effect them. You remember
The daughter of this lord?

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Admiringly, my liege. At first
I stuck my choice upon her, ere my heart
Durst make too bold a herald of my tongue;
Where the impression of mine eye infixing,
Contempt his scornful perspective did lend me,
Which warp’d the line of every other favor,
Scorn’d a fair color, or express’d it stol’n,
Extended or contracted all proportions
To a most hideous object. Thence it came
That she whom all men prais’d, and whom myself,
Since I have lost, have lov’d, was in mine eye
The dust that did offend it.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Well excus’d.
That thou didst love her, strikes some scores away
From the great compt; but love that comes too late,
Like a remorseful pardon slowly carried,
To the great sender turns a sour offense,
Crying, “That’s good that’s gone.” Our rash faults
Make trivial price of serious things we have,
Not knowing them until we know their grave.
Oft our displeasures, to ourselves unjust,
Destroy our friends, and after weep their dust;
Our own love waking cries to see what’s done,
While shameful hate sleeps out the afternoon.
Be this sweet Helen’s knell, and now forget her.
Send forth your amoroustoken for fair Maudlin.
The main consents are had, and here we’ll stay
To see our widower’s second marriage-day.

sp.speaker: COUNT.
sp.l: Which better than the first, O dear heaven, bless!
Or, ere they meet, in me, O nature, cesse!

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Come on, my son, in whom my house’s name
Must be digested; give a favor from you
To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter,
That she may quickly come.
By my old beard,
And ev’ry hair that’s on’t, Helen, that’s dead,
Was a sweet creature; such a ring as this,
The last that e’er I took her leave at court,
I saw upon her finger.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Hers it was not.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Now pray you let me see it; for mine eye,
While I was speaking, oft was fasten’d to’t.
This ring was mine, and when I gave it Helen,
I bade her, if her fortunes ever stood
Necessitied to help, that by this token
I would relieve her. Had you that craft to reave her
Of what should stead her most?

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: My gracious sovereign,
Howe’er it pleases you to take it so,
The ring was never hers.

sp.speaker: COUNT.
sp.l: Son, on my life,
I have seen her wear it, and she reckon’d it
At her live’s rate.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: I am sure I saw her wear it.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: You are deceiv’d, my lord, she never saw it.
In Florence was it from a casement thrown me,
Wrapp’d in a paper, which contain’d the name
Of her that threw it. Noble she was, and thought
I stood engag’d; but when I had subscrib’d
To mine own fortune, and inform’d her fully
I could not answer in that course of honor
As she had made the overture, she ceas’d
In heavysatisfaction, and would never
Receive the ring again.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Plutus himself,
That knows the tinct and multiplying med’cine,
Hath not in nature’s mystery more science
Than I have in this ring. ’Twas mine, ’twas Helen’s,
Whoever gave it you. Then if you know
That you are well acquainted with yourself,
Confess ’twas hers, and by what rough enforcement
You got it from her. She call’d the saints to surety
That she would never put it from her finger,
Unless she gave it to yourself in bed,
Where you have never come, or sent it us
Upon her great disaster.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: She never saw it.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Thou speak’st it falsely, as I love mine honor,
And mak’st conjectural fears to come into me,
Which I would fain shut out. If it should prove
That thou art so inhuman—’twill not prove so;
And yet I know not: thou didst hate her deadly,
And she is dead, which nothing but to close
Her eyes myself could win me to believe,
More than to see this ring. Take him away.
My fore-past proofs, howe’er the matter fall,
Shall tax my fears of little vanity,
Having vainly fear’d too little. Away with him!
We’ll sift this matter further.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: If you shall prove
This ring was ever hers, you shall as easy
Prove that I husbanded her bed in Florence,
Where yet she never was.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: I am wrapp’d in dismalthinkings.

sp.speaker: GENT.
sp.l: Gracious sovereign,
Whether I have been to blame or no, I know not.
Here’s a petition from a Florentine,
Who hath for four or five removes come short
To tender it herself. I undertook it,
Vanquish’d thereto by the fair grace and speech
Of the poor suppliant, who by this I know
Is here attending. Her business looks in her
With an importingvisage, and she told me,
In a sweet verbal brief, it did concern
Your Highness with herself.

l.recite: “Upon his many protestations to marry me when his wife was dead, I blush to say it, he won me. Now is the Count Roussillon a widower, his vows are forfeited to me, and my honor’s paid to him. He stole from Florence, taking no leave, and I follow him to his country for justice. Grant it me, O King, in you it best lies; otherwise a seducer flourishes, and a poor maid is undone. Diana Capilet.”

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: I will buy me a son-in-law in a fair, and toll for this. I’ll none of him.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: The heavens have thought well on thee, Lafew,
To bring forth this discov’ry. Seek these suitors.
Go speedily, and bring again the Count.
I am afeard the life of Helen, lady,
Was foully snatch’d.

sp.speaker: COUNT.
sp.l: Now, justice on the doers!

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: I wonder, sir, sith wives are monsters to you,
And that you fly them as you swear them lordship,
Yet you desire to marry. What woman’s that?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: I am, my lord, a wretched Florentine,
Derived from the ancient Capilet.
My suit, as I do understand, you know,
And therefore know how far I may be pitied.

sp.speaker: WID.
sp.l: I am her mother, sir, whose age and honor
Both suffer under this complaint we bring,
And both shall cease, without your remedy.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Come hither, Count, do you know these women?

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: My lord, I neither can nor will deny
But that I know them. Do they charge me further?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Why do you look so strange upon your wife?

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: She’s none of mine, my lord.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: If you shall marry,
You give away this hand, and that is mine;
You give away heaven’s vows, and those are mine;
You give away myself, which is known mine;
For I by vow am so embodied yours,
That she which marries you must marry me,
Either both or none.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Your reputation comes too short for my daughter, you are no husband for her.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: My lord, this is a fond and desp’rate creature,
Whom sometime I have laugh’d with. Let your Highness
Lay a more noble thought upon mine honor
Than for to think that I would sink it here.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Sir, for my thoughts, you have them ill to friend
Till your deeds gain them; fairer prove your honor
Than in my thought it lies.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Good my lord,
Ask him upon his oath, if he does think
He had not my virginity.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: What say’st thou to her?

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: She’s impudent, my lord,
And was a commongamester to the camp.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: He does me wrong, my lord; if I were so,
He might have bought me at a common price.
Do not believe him. O, behold this ring,
Whose high respect and rich validity
Did lack a parallel; yet for all that
He gave it to a commoner a’ th’ camp,
If I be one.

sp.speaker: COUNT.
sp.l: He blushes, and ’tis hit.
Of six preceding ancestors, that gem,
Conferr’d by testament to th’ sequentissue,
Hath it been owed and worn. This is his wife,
That ring’s a thousand proofs.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Methought you said
You saw one here in court could witness it.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: I did, my lord, but loath am to produce
So bad an instrument. His name’s Parolles.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: I saw the man today, if man he be.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Find him, and bring him hither.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: What of him?
He’s quoted for a most perfidious slave,
With all the spots a’ th’ world tax’d and debosh’d,
Whose nature sickens but to speak a truth.
Am I or that or this for what he’ll utter,
That will speak any thing?

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: She hath that ring of yours.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: I think she has. Certain it is I lik’d her,
And boarded her i’ th’ wanton way of youth.
She knew her distance, and did angle for me,
Madding my eagerness with her restraint,
As all impediments in fancy’s course
Are motives of more fancy, and in fine,
Her inf’nite cunning, with her moderngrace,
Subdu’d me to her rate. She got the ring,
And I had that which any inferior might
At market-price have bought.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: I must be patient.
You that have turn’d off a first so noble wife,
May justly diet me. I pray you yet
(Since you lack virtue, I will lose a husband)
Send for your ring, I will return it home,
And give me mine again.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: I have it not.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: What ring was yours, I pray you?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Sir, much like
The same upon your finger.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Know you this ring? This ring was his of late.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: And this was it I gave him, being a-bed.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: The story then goes false, you threw it him
Out of a casement.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: I have spoke the truth.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: My lord, I do confess the ring was hers.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: You boggleshrewdly, every feather starts you.
Is this the man you speak of?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Ay, my lord.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Tell me, sirrah—but tell me true, I charge you,
Not fearing the displeasure of your master,
Which on your just proceeding I’ll keep off⁠—
By him and by this woman here what know you?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: So please your Majesty, my master hath been an honorable gentleman. Tricks he hath had in him, which gentlemen have.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Come, come, to th’ purpose. Did he love this woman?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Faith, sir, he did love her, but how?

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: How, I pray you?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: He did love her, sir, as a gentleman loves a woman.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: How is that?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: He lov’d her, sir, and lov’d her not.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: As thou art a knave, and no knave. What an equivocalcompanion is this!

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: I am a poor man, and at your Majesty’s command.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: He’s a good drum, my lord, but a naughty orator.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Do you know he promis’d me marriage?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Faith, I know more than I’ll speak.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: But wilt thou not speak all thou know’st?

sp.speaker: PAR.
sp.l: Yes, so please your Majesty. I did go between them as I said, but more than that, he lov’d her, for indeed he was mad for her, and talk’d of Satan and of Limbo and of Furies and I know not what. Yet I was in that credit with them at that time that I knew of their going to bed, and of other motions, as promising her marriage, and things which would derive me ill will to speak of; therefore I will not speak what I know.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Thou hast spoken all already, unless thou canst say they are married. But thou art too fine in thy evidence, therefore stand aside.
This ring you say was yours?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Ay, my good lord.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Where did you buy it? Or who gave it you?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: It was not given me, nor I did not buy it.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Who lent it you?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: It was not lent me neither.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Where did you find it then?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: I found it not.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: If it were yours by none of all these ways,
How could you give it him?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: I never gave it him.

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: This woman’s an easy glove, my lord, she goes off and on at pleasure.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: This ring was mine, I gave it his first wife.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: It might be yours or hers for aught I know.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Take her away, I do not like her now,
To prison with her; and away with him.
Unless thou tell’st me where thou hadst this ring,
Thou diest within this hour.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: I’ll never tell you.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Take her away.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: I’ll put in bail, my liege.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: I think thee now some common customer.

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: By Jove, if ever I knew man, ’twas you.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Wherefore hast thou accus’d him all this while?

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Because he’s guilty, and he is not guilty.
He knows I am no maid, and he’ll swear to’t;
I’ll swear I am a maid, and he knows not.
Great King, I am no strumpet, by my life;
I am either maid, or else this old man’s wife.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: She does abuse our ears. To prison with her!

sp.speaker: DIA.
sp.l: Good mother, fetch my bail.
Stay, royal sir.
The jeweler that owes the ring is sent for,
And he shall surety me. But for this lord,
Who hath abus’d me, as he knows himself,
Though yet he never harm’d me, here I quit him.
He knows himself my bed he hath defil’d,
And at that time he got his wife with child.
Dead though she be, she feels her young one kick.
So there’s my riddle: one that’s dead is quick⁠—
And now behold the meaning.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Is there no exorcist
Beguiles the truer office of mine eyes?
Is’t real that I see?

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: No, my good lord,
’Tis but the shadow of a wife you see,
The name, and not the thing.

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: Both, both. O, pardon!

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: O my good lord, when I was like this maid,
I found you wondrous kind. There is your ring,
And look you, here’s your letter. This it says:
“When from my finger you can get this ring,
And are by me with child, etc.” This is done.
Will you be mine now you are doubly won?

sp.speaker: BER.
sp.l: If she, my liege, can make me know this clearly,
I’ll love her dearly, ever, ever dearly.

sp.speaker: HEL.
sp.l: If it appear not plain and prove untrue,
Deadly divorce step between me and you!
O my dear mother, do I see you living?

sp.speaker: LAF.
sp.l: Mine eyes smell onions, I shall weep anon.
Good Tom Drum, lend me a handkercher. So, I thank thee; wait on me home, I’ll make sport with thee. Let thy curtsies alone, they are scurvy ones.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Let us from point to point this story know,
To make the even truth in pleasure flow.
If thou beest yet a fresh uncropped flower,
Choose thou thy husband, and I’ll pay thy dower,
For I can guess that by thy honest aid
Thou kept’st a wife herself, thyself a maid.
Of that and all the progress, more and less,
Resolvedly more leisure shall express.
All yet seems well, and if it end so meet,
The bitter past, more welcome is the sweet.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: The king’s a beggar, now the play is done;
All is well ended, if this suit be won,
That you express content; which we will pay,
With strife to please you, day exceeding day.
Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts;
Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts.
